elements.content: The reaction of the ligand rac-(R,S)-2,2‘-bipyridine-3,3‘-dicarboxylic acid 1,1‘-dioxide [(R,S)-H2BDCD] with Mn(CH3COO)2·2H2O gives a novel 2D coordination polymer, {Mn[(R,S)-BDCD](H2O)} (1), which contains a dimeric Mn(II) core with dioxide (O,O atoms of carboxylate ligands) as the bridge units and exhibits ferromagnetic interaction between Mn2+ ions.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of the ligand rac-(R,S)-2,2‘-bipyridine-3,3‘-dicarboxylic acid 1,1‘-dioxide [(R,S)-H2BDCD] with Mn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O gives a novel 2D coordination polymer, {Mn[(R,S)-BDCD](H2O)} (1), which contains a dimeric Mn(II) core with dioxide (O,O atoms of carboxylate ligands) as the bridge units and exhibits ferromagnetic interaction between Mn2+ ions.

elements.content: The reaction of the ligand rac-(R,S)-2,2‘-bipyridine-3,3‘-dicarboxylic acid 1,1‘-dioxide [(R,S)-H2BDCD] with Mn(CH3COO)2·2H2O gives one novel 2D coordination polymer, {Mn[(R,S)-BDCD](H2O)} (1), which contains a core with dioxide (O,O atoms of carboxylate ligands) as the bridge units and exhibits ferromagnetic interaction between Mn2+ ions.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of the ligand rac-(R,S)-2,2‘-bipyridine-3,3‘-dicarboxylic acid 1,1‘-dioxide [(R,S)-H2BDCD] with Mn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O gives one novel 2D coordination polymer, {Mn[(R,S)-BDCD](H2O)} (1), which contains a core with dioxide (O,O atoms of carboxylate ligands) as the bridge units and exhibits ferromagnetic interaction between Mn2+ ions.

elements.content: Metal−organic hybrid materials of paramagnetic metal ions exhibiting extended structures are of intense current interest in the field of molecular magnetism and materials chemistry due to their fascinating structural diversities and potential application as functional materials. Dinuclear manganese complexes were used as models of an Mn catalase, and tetranuclear complexes were known to exist at the reactive center for photosynthetic water oxidation. In the field of magnetic materials, polynuclear manganese complexes with large spin multiplicities and uniaxial magnetic anisotropies have attracted much attention for their unique solid-sate properties such as superparamagnetism and quantum spin tunneling. From the viewpoint of constructing such compounds, ferromagnetically coupled dinuclear manganese compounds are considered to be the simplest models for understanding magnetic interactions between metal centers and paramagnetic building units of polymeric architectures. Numerous dimeric manganese(II) complexes have been synthesized, but those that are ferromagnetically coupled are relatively rare. Herein, we report the synthesis, structure, and magnetic properties of a ferromagnetically coupled dinuclear manganese coordination polymer with a tetradentate ligand.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic hybrid materials of paramagnetic metal ions exhibiting extended structures are of intense current interest in the field of molecular magnetism and materials chemistry due to their fascinating structural diversities and potential application as functional materials. Dinuclear manganese complexes were used as models of an Mn catalase, and tetranuclear complexes were known to exist at the reactive center for photosynthetic water oxidation. In the field of magnetic materials, polynuclear manganese complexes with large spin multiplicities and uniaxial magnetic anisotropies have attracted much attention for their unique solid-sate properties such as superparamagnetism and quantum spin tunneling. From the viewpoint of constructing such compounds, ferromagnetically coupled dinuclear manganese compounds are considered to be the simplest models for understanding magnetic interactions between metal centers and paramagnetic building units of polymeric architectures. Numerous dimeric manganese(II) complexes have been synthesized, but those that are ferromagnetically coupled are relatively rare. Herein, we report the synthesis, structure, and magnetic properties of a ferromagnetically coupled dinuclear manganese coordination polymer with a tetradentate ligand.

elements.content: The complex {Mn[(R,S)-BDCD](H2O)} (BDCD = rac-(R,S)-2,2‘-bipyridine-3,3‘-dicarboxylic acid 1,1‘-dioxide) was prepared by the treatment of the tetradentate ligand (R,S)-H2BDCD with Mn(OAc)2·2H2O under the solvothermal reaction conditions (Scheme ). The IR spectrum of complex 1 shows three very strong peaks at 1664, 1620, and 1598 cm-1 combined with two moderately strong peaks at 1429 and 1401 cm-1(s) suggesting that the carboxylic acid group of [(R,S)-BDCD] persists in 1. In addition, a broad peak at 3300−3500 cm-1 suggests that there is a coordinated or crystalline water in the coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: The complex {Mn[(R,S)-BDCD](H2O)} (BDCD = rac-(R,S)-2,2‘-bipyridine-3,3‘-dicarboxylic acid 1,1‘-dioxide) was prepared by the treatment of the tetradentate ligand (R,S)-H2BDCD with Mn(OAc)2⋅2H2O under the solvothermal reaction conditions (Scheme ). The IR spectrum of complex 1 shows three very strong peaks at 1664, 1620, and 1598 cm-1 combined with two moderately strong peaks at 1429 and 1401 cm-1(s) suggesting that the carboxylic acid group of [(R,S)-BDCD] persists in 1. In addition, a broad peak at 3300-3500 cm-1 suggests that there is a coordinated or crystalline water in the coordination polymers.

elements.content: The crystal structure determination of 1 {Mn[(R,S)-BDCD](H2O)} reveals that it is a complicated 2D coordination polymer containing Mn2 II as the connecting node with carboxylates as the bridging spacer. The Mn centers are coordinated by six O atoms:  three O atoms from a monodentate coordinated carboxylate group, two O atoms from N-oxides, and one O atom from water, resulting in the formation of a six-coordinate metal center with a slightly distorted octahedron, as shown in Figure . Overall each (R,S)-BDCD ligand acts as a tetradentate bridge to link three Mn centers using two carboxylate groups and two O atoms from N-oxide bonds, giving a 2D square grid with a cavity dimension of 8.207 × 8.207 Å2 containing two Mn and two O atoms as the bridge unit (Figure ). In addition, Figure also clearly reveals the true relationship of the two manganese centers; that is, the two Mn centers form two edge-sharing octahedra that are relevant to the magnetic interactions between the two metal centers. To the best of our knowledge, compound 1 is the first transition metal coordination polymer containing dimeric Mn(II) with dioxide as a bridge unit as corners. Furthermore, the relationship between two adjacent layers can be best described as AA-type stacking (Figure ). Interestingly, the dihedral angle between two phenyl rings is ca. 67.2° to result in the formation of a slightly distorted seven-membered ring [Mn1O1N1C7C12N2C19] chair configuration (Figure ). In addition, there is a larger nine-membered ring [Mn1O3AC8AC11AC7AC12AC10AC14AO4A] (Figure ). Finally, as expected, the bond distances of the Mn−Ocarboxylate (2.111(2)−2.219(2) Å) are the longest among the three Mn−O distances [Mn(1)−Ooxide 2.194(2) to Mn(1)−O(1) 2.208(2) Å and Mn(1)−Owater 2.176(2)Å] in 1. Unexceptionally, the bond lengths of C−C, C−O, and C−N are normal.
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure determination of 1 {Mn[(R,S)-BDCD](H2O)} reveals that it is a complicated 2D coordination polymer containing Mn2 II as the connecting node with carboxylates as the bridging spacer. The Mn centers are coordinated by six O atoms: three O atoms from a monodentate coordinated carboxylate group, two O atoms from N-oxides, and one O atom from water, resulting in the formation of a six-coordinate metal center with a slightly distorted octahedron, as shown in Figure . Overall each (R,S)-BDCD ligand acts as a tetradentate bridge to link three Mn centers using two carboxylate groups and two O atoms from N-oxide bonds, giving a 2D square grid with a cavity dimension of 8.207 × 8.207 Å2 containing two Mn and two O atoms as the bridge unit (Figure ). In addition, Figure  also clearly reveals the true relationship of the two manganese centers; that is, the two Mn centers form two edge-sharing octahedra that are relevant to the magnetic interactions between the two metal centers. To the best of our knowledge, compound 1 is the first transition metal coordination polymer containing dimeric Mn(II) with dioxide as a bridge unit as corners. Furthermore, the relationship between two adjacent layers can be best described as AA-type stacking (Figure ). Interestingly, the dihedral angle between two phenyl rings is ca. 67.2° to result in the formation of a slightly distorted seven-membered ring [Mn1O1N1C7C12N2C19] chair configuration (Figure ). In addition, there is a larger nine-membered ring [Mn1O3AC8AC11AC7AC12AC10AC14AO4A] (Figure ). Finally, as expected, the bond distances of the Mn-Ocarboxylate (2.111(2)-2.219(2) Å) are the longest among the three Mn-O distances [Mn(1)-Ooxide 2.194(2) to Mn(1)-O(1) 2.208(2) Å and Mn(1)-Owater 2.176(2)Å] in 1. Unexceptionally, the bond lengths of C-C, C-O, and C-N are normal.

elements.content: An asymmetric unit of1 in which a Mn dimer is connected through two carboxylates. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (deg) are as follows:  Mn1−O4A, 2.112(2); Mn1−O3B, 2.1498(19); Mn1−O1W, 2.165(2); Mn1−O2, 2.194(2); Mn1−O1, 2.208(2); Mn1−O3A, 2.220(2); O4A−Mn1−O3B, 157.62(8); O4A−Mn1−O1W, 95.31(10); O3B−Mn1−O1W, 98.72(9); O4A−Mn1−O2, 87.10(9); O3B−Mn1−O2, 83.75(8); O1W−Mn1−O2, 165.26(9); O4A−Mn1−O1, 92.66(8); O3B−Mn1−O1, 105.84(8); O1W−Mn1−O1, 84.87(8); O2−Mn1−O1, 80.50(7); O4A−Mn1−O3A, 83.90(8); O3−Mn1−O3A, 77.08(8); O1W−Mn1−O3A, 97.44(9); O2−Mn1−O3A, 97.27(8); O1−Mn1−O3A, 176.02(7); N1−O1−Mn1, 114.99(15); N2−O2−Mn1, 115.75(15); C14−O3−Mn1C, 138.57(18); C(14)−O3−Mn1D, 116.50(17); Mn1C−O3−Mn1D, 102.92(8); C8A−O4−Mn1D,163.5(2). Symmetry codes are as follows:  (A) x + 1/2, y − 1/2, −z + 1/2; (B) x + 1/2, −y + 1/2, z − 1/2; (C) x − 1/2, −y + 1/2, z + 1/2; (D) −x + 1/2, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2.
(a) 2D network representation of1 and (b) a simplified 2D network perspective view of 1.

elements.content: To investigate the stability of this framework, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) on the crystalline samples was carried out. The TGA curve of 1 (Figure ) showed that one discrete weight loss (2.09%) occurred between 25 and 172 °C, corresponding to the removal of two water molecules per subunit (2.89% calculated). The framework is stable at 172−225 °C. Beyond this temperature, decomposition of the network was observed.
elements.clean_text: To investigate the stability of this framework, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) on the crystalline samples was carried out. The  TGA curve of 1 (Figure ) showed that one discrete weight loss (2.09%) occurred between 25 and 172 °C, corresponding to the removal of two water molecules per subunit (2.89% calculated). The framework is stable at 172-225 °C. Beyond this temperature, decomposition of the network was observed.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility of 1 was measured in the 2−300 K temperature range and is shown in Figure with χM T versus T plots. The experimental χM T value at 300 K is 4.26 emu mol-1 K, which is somewhat lower than the spin-only value (4.38 emu mol-1 K) expected for uncoupled high-spin Mn(II) ions. Upon cooling, the χM T products increase slowly at about 50 K and then increase rapidly on further cooling. These features indicate a dominant ferromagnetic interaction in 1. The oxidation state of Mn ions in 1 is +2 by the saturation magnetization at 2 K, and the results are in good agreement with the crystal structure determination mentioned before.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic susceptibility of 1 was measured in the 2-300 K temperature range and is shown in Figure  with χM T versus T plots. The experimental χM T value at 300 K is 4.26 emu mol-1 K, which is somewhat lower than the spin-only value (4.38 emu mol-1 K) expected for uncoupled high-spin Mn(II) ions. Upon cooling, the χM T products increase slowly at about 50 K and then increase rapidly on further cooling. These features indicate a dominant ferromagnetic interaction in 1. The oxidation state of Mn ions in 1 is +2 by the saturation magnetization at 2 K, and the results are  in good agreement with the crystal structure determination mentioned before.

elements.content: In summary, we have synthesized a two-dimensional manganese coordination polymer exhibiting ferromagnetic behaviors under hydrothermal reaction that contains a dimeric Mn(II) core. The results presented here demonstrate the value of hydrothermal approaches in the generation of novel complexes with potentially useful physical properties, combined with a well-designed building block.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have synthesized a two-dimensional manganese coordination polymer exhibiting ferromagnetic behaviors under hydrothermal reaction that contains a dimeric Mn(II) core. The results presented here demonstrate the value of hydrothermal approaches in the generation of novel complexes with potentially useful physical properties, combined with a well-designed building block.

cln_elements.content:
To investigate the stability of this framework, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) on the crystalline samples was carried out. The TGA curve of 1 (Figure ) showed that one discrete weight loss (2.09%) occurred between 25 and 172 °C, corresponding to the removal of two water molecules per subunit (2.89% calculated). The framework is stable at 172−225 °C. Beyond this temperature, decomposition of the network was observed.

The magnetic susceptibility of 1 was measured in the 2−300 K temperature range and is shown in Figure with χM T versus T plots. The experimental χM T value at 300 K is 4.26 emu mol-1 K, which is somewhat lower than the spin-only value (4.38 emu mol-1 K) expected for uncoupled high-spin Mn(II) ions. Upon cooling, the χM T products increase slowly at about 50 K and then increase rapidly on further cooling. These features indicate a dominant ferromagnetic interaction in 1. The oxidation state of Mn ions in 1 is +2 by the saturation magnetization at 2 K, and the results are in good agreement with the crystal structure determination mentioned before.
cln_elements.clean_text:
To investigate the stability of this framework, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) on the crystalline samples was carried out. The  TGA curve of 1 (Figure ) showed that one discrete weight loss (2.09%) occurred between 25 and 172 °C, corresponding to the removal of two water molecules per subunit (2.89% calculated). The framework is stable at 172-225 °C. Beyond this temperature, decomposition of the network was observed. 

The magnetic susceptibility of 1 was measured in the 2-300 K temperature range and is shown in Figure  with χM T versus T plots. The experimental χM T value at 300 K is 4.26 emu mol-1 K, which is somewhat lower than the spin-only value (4.38 emu mol-1 K) expected for uncoupled high-spin Mn(II) ions. Upon cooling, the χM T products increase slowly at about 50 K and then increase rapidly on further cooling. These features indicate a dominant ferromagnetic interaction in 1. The oxidation state of Mn ions in 1 is +2 by the saturation magnetization at 2 K, and the results are  in good agreement with the crystal structure determination mentioned before.

metadata.title:
A Novel 2D Manganese(II) Coordination Polymer Exhibiting Ferromagnetic
Interaction
